entry.title: How to visit a Peely Island Head in LEGO Fortnite
entry.summary:
LEGO Fortnite's Island Heads are one of the rarest objects in the game, often tying into Weekly Quests. On top of that, its vague instructions offer little insight into what to look for, making it more difficult than it already is.
So, if you're lost (like I was), here's how to visit a Peely Island Head in LEGO Fortnite.
Where to find Peely Island Head in LEGO Fortnite
Like the Llama Island Head and NaNa Village, there's no universal location that spawns the Peely Island Head. However, I find it best to use a seed from another player to fast-track things a bit more. The key thing you need to look out for is a banana statue, which likely triggers a golem appearance.
I used the seed '13.89.36.54.63' from the Reddit user TatoMcgoo to locate my first statue. The world boasts the quickest way to find the Peely Island Head in LEGO Fortnite, considering that it's not too far from the base. Go to the coordinates '0.84, 4.775, 0.23' to find it atop a hill.
Screenshot by Destructoid
Looking to the left of Haven's Village, you'll quickly see the banana statue from there. But be warned of the formidable golem that lingers there.
Screenshot by Destructoid
As long as you approach the statue, it should mark the completion of the Peely Island Head mission. If you're up for it, you can try to defeat the banana golem to gain some resources. Weapons like the Star Wars lightsaber and the cannon prove effective with it. You should also keep your distance since its spinning attack can be deadly. Then, you can start looting the Island Head's chest to farm additional rewards.
Exchange the Studs you've earned from the mission to obtain cosmetics from the LEGO Pass. Complete more quests to reach the final tier, providing the exclusive Nana Hut build.

entry.title: How to get Red Rocks in LEGO Fortnite
entry.summary:
As a survival crafting game, LEGO Fortnite offers a wide range of materials for recipes and upgrades. One such resource is the Red Rock, a crucial ingredient for crafting powerful weapons. We'll show you how to get Red Rock in LEGO Fortnite and what to use it with.
Where to find Red Rocks in LEGO Fortnite
You can mine Red Rocks anywhere on the LEGO Fortnite's Lost Isles map. They appear similar to the Granite, but you can tell the difference through their coloring. To give you an idea of what to expect, here's an image of the two together (Red Rock on the left and Granite on the right):
Screenshot by Destructoid
Unlike the Granite, there isn't a way to pick up the Red Rock, so you'll need a Pickaxe. Use rarities like Uncommon or Epic on the tool to mine those rocks. Common (wood) is the only one that doesn't work since it doesn't have enough strength as an early material. I recommend farming a whole lot of them to better prepare for future builds.
What to use Red Rocks for in LEGO Fortnite
Red Rock is not just a resource; it's a key to unlocking a world of crafting possibilities in LEGO Fortnite. Use it to craft several Lost Isles recipes, such as the Explorer's Machete, Flint-Knock Pistol, Boom Shield, and Throwing Spear. It'll coat all your tools with a dark red shade, similar to the Red Rock's designs.
Screenshot by Destructoid
In addition to the gear, furniture also harnesses a few recipes, using the Zesty Single and Double Beds. More designs may be associated with it, but these bunch seem to be the primary ones for builds.
If you're trying to improve your base, you'll need 15 Red Rocks and 10 Mahogany Rods to unlock Village Level 4. It also mandates a few objectives, like the Complete a Pirate Camp. Make sure to have enough residents in your house, too, to satisfy the Upgrade Requirements. In return, you'll earn rewards for your efforts, providing more uses for villagers and animals.

entry.title: How to complete a Pirate Camp in LEGO Fortnite
entry.summary:
When you first begin your upgrade journey in Lost Isles, you'll come across a rather peculiar task. The objective enlists travelers to "complete a Pirate Camp" in order to improve the village. Find out how to find a Pirate Camp in LEGO Fortnite, including how to satisfy the quest's requirements.
LEGO Fortnite Complete a Pirate Camp quest guide
To satisfy the Complete a Pirate Camp quest in LEGO Fortnite, you must eliminate all pirates in their hub and loot their chests. But now that begs the question: Where do you find these Pirate Camps? Well, the beach seems to be the quickest way to locate them, as they are easily noticeable with their smoke signals. They'll also appear in other areas, so keep a sharp eye on your surroundings.
Image by Destructoid
Be warned that pirates hanging out by campfire do not count towards this mission. Look for a bunch of houses instead, and you should see those freebooters lounging around. Expect some resistance from them and try to come prepared with suitable weapons, such as the Musket, Flintlock Pistol, and Cannon. Tool upgrades can be helpful, too, so make sure to grab Tomes for maximum damage.
Once you've knocked enough heads, you'll still need to do one last thing to complete the quest. Search for a chest inside one of the buildings and loot it to earn the achievement. If you don't do this step, it won't count towards the Village Level 3 upgrade (even those who eliminate all pirates).
Screenshot by Destructoid
Return to your Village Square, and you'll see a check for the LEGO Fortnite Pirate Camp quest. However, it still requires other minor tasks, like recruiting visitors and crafting a Health Charm. The upgrade also mandates Mahogany Rods and Red Rocks deriving from the new Lost Isle area. Finish and collect them all to maximize your village.

entry.title: EA FC 25: How to send a player from SBC Storage to your club
entry.summary:
The SBC storage is one of the more exciting additions in EA FC 25's Ultimate Team, but it can be slightly confusing for many.
The storage works as an efficient way to store your duplicate untradeables, which can't be sold elsewhere. This space can store up to 100 duplicate cards. But what if you want to move one of those items to solve an SBC or move it to your club? Once you know the process, it becomes an easy job.
How to move a player from SBC storage in EA FC 25
Whenever you open any untradeable pack and get one or more duplicates, they're automatically stored in the storage. At first, there will be a prompt about sending them to SBC storage. You should turn the prompt off, as it can get tedious later in the cycle. If you want to move the card from storage, here's how to do it.
Image via Destructoid
Open any SBC that you want to complete. In this image, I wanted to complete the first task of the David Alaba Flashback objective.
Select a spot.
Press R1/RB to scroll to SBC storage.
Select a card from there. This card will be transferred to the SBC squad. Press on it, and you'll get the option to move the item to your club.
If you want to submit the item in a SBC, keep it where it is.
Image via Destructoid
There's a bug that sometimes prevents you from sending the item to your club. In that case, choose to send the card to the SBC storage once again and rinse and repeat the process mentioned here. That should be the job you wanted to do in the first place.
I love the idea that they have added duplicate storage, and it has made my life easier at the start of a new Ultimate Team. I don't have to bother about shifting the duplicates, and I can also build up a stack of cards for a popular SBC when that arrives in the future in EA FC 25.

entry.title: What is “non physical damage” in Diablo 4? Explained
entry.summary:
In Diablo 4, some of the gear pieces you obtain may have the “non-physical damage” trait, but what it means isn’t too straightforward. Is it an affix worth keeping? If so, here’s what it means and what it applies to.
What is non-physical damage in Diablo 4?
Non-physical damage is any damage type that isn’t labeled as physical damage, as straightforward as it sounds.
For example, if you are leveling a Druid, all the core skills will be labeled as physical damage except for Lightning Storm. If you are equipping gear that gives a bonus to non-physical damage, you want to make sure that skills listed in your class’ tree have any other label than physical.
A class like a Druid will have a mix of the two, so make sure that you aren’t dipping into a damage type that you aren’t casting. It’s always best to specialize in specific damage types so you won't lose out on any bonuses.
Screenshot by Destructoid
Is non-physical damage good?
In many cases, the non-physical damage boost can heavily increase your DPS in Diablo 4. This works exceptionally well for Sorcerers since all of their damage will come from fire, lightning, or cold. These are all examples of non-physical damage.
Most high-tier Sorcerer builds will either make use of the Tal Rasha’s Iridescent Loop, or the Fractured Winterglass because of the strong affixes they have. What they both also have are significant boosts to non-physical damage.
It’s basically a direct damage upgrade by equipping these items, even if you’re running unoptimized builds that don’t benefit much from their key passives.
Rogues will also benefit from this when imbuing skills. Just know that just because you’re using a projectile attack doesn’t automatically mean it’s non-physical. The skill on your tree will tell you what type of damage it is, even if there is some type of class-specific element.

entry.title: WoW guilds in disarray as Blizzard unable to restore banks wiped due to bug
entry.summary:
Since August, World of Warcraft guilds have been reporting a troubling bug: their guild banks, where any member of the guild can store resources, items, and even the game's rarest of loot (like mounts), were wiped out. Whether completely emptied or simply missing items, users reported that the fruits of their labor were vanishing into thin air. As of September, Blizzard's response has left many players with their heads in their hands.
Some items will never be recovered
Community Manager Linxy said in a blogpost over on the Blizzard forums that the core issue was caused by the enabling of cross-realm guilds. As a part of The War Within, many limitations on players' ability to play, trade, and share with each other across both faction and realm were dissolved, making for a more communal experience across the player base.
But that convenience comes at a cost. "Due to how some of the data was lost, we've reached a point where the result will be an incomplete restoration for some guilds, and we do not have a way to restore the remaining missing items for them," says Linxy. Data loss is a backend developer's worst nightmare, especially when that data could be 19-year-old mounts, collectables, and items not even obtainable in the game anymore.
The affected community, needless to say, is in shambles. The bug didn't affect everyone, mind you, but those it has have lost, at worst, nearly two decades' worth of stashed items. The best we can hope for is some form of compensation to those affected, but without the data that shows which items were lost, it really isn't going to be possible to get that history back.

entry.title: Where to find Onions in Disney Dreamlight Valley
entry.summary:
Onions in Disney Dreamlight Valley are a gateway to many recipes in the game. You can make dishes like Arendellian Pickled Herring and Seared Rainbow Trout with Onions in this Disney title.
Screenshot by Destructoid
Screenshot by Destructoid
How to get Onions in Disney Dreamlight Valley
The main way to get Onions in Disney Dreamlight Valley is to purchase their seeds from Goofy's Stall. They can be bought for 50 Gold Coins each from the Forest of Valor location. Once you've dug a spot for them to grow, place them in the soil and water them. These onion seeds take around an hour to grow and will need to be watered twice.
There is a chance that there's already an Onion growing within Wall-E's garden, however. If you've finished the little robot's realm in the castle and completed his story quests, you'll gain access to his garden in your valley. This is where he grows all sorts of vegetables and other ingredients. Upgrade this space to maximize your chances of finding an Onion within this batch.
How to make Arendellian Pickled Herring
The best Onion dish you can make with your newfound ingredient is the Arendellian Pickled Herring because it's a five-star meal. You'll need the following ingredients for it:
Herring
Onion
Garlic
Any sort of spice
Lemon
Garlic grows within the ground of the Forest of Valor. Lemons also grow on trees within the Forest of Valor but you can find them in the Glade of Trust too. Herring can be caught in the waters of Dazzle Beach and Glade of Trust within white puddles.
Once you have all of the ingredients, gather them into a pot inside a kitchen. After making Arendellian Pickled Herring, you can sell it for 532 Gold Coins. However, you may want to save it if you haven't completed all of Elsa's quests yet as she'll request the meal at one point.

entry.title: LEVEL-5 announces new Yokai Watch title Holy Horror Mansion
entry.summary:
As part of its 2024 Vision Showcase, LEVEL-5 has released the first teaser trailer for the next Yokai Watch! concept, Holy Horror Mansion. The game is described as a ‘Ghost Craft RPG’, and everything we currently know comes direct the trailer itself.
The game is set to center around Ten Lordland, a boy who lives in a mansion atop an apartment block that is owned by his Grandmother. The apartment block, which is also a portal to the underworld, is filled with spirits that are discovered by Ten after he uses a mysterious camera and one of his nose hairs turns into a green ghost.
Yes, you read that correctly.
Image via LEVEL-5/YouTube
This green ghost is capable of possessing objects and turning them into Yokai-esque monsters, and he doesn’t come into the world alone. His friends, blue and pink ghost, will help to craft unique monsters and create worlds to explore respectively.
Interestingly, as part of the teaser trailer, a familiar face made a rather unexpected appearance:
Image via LEVEL-5/YouTube
I’m not sure if you’ll remember pen-pineapple-apple-pen, but I sure do; and I definitely wasn’t expecting to see PIKOTARO to show up in a video game trailer, but I’m glad he did. Although having said that, I’ve now got his song stuck in my head and it's not likely to leave for the next week.
Little is known about a potential release date for Holy Horror Mansion just yet, and even less is known about which platforms it will be coming to. If previous Yokai Watch! titles are anything to go by, it’s likely that Holy Horror Mansion will make its home on Nintendo Switch. Depending on the release date, it may even be an early release for the Switch's successor console.
More information will be coming in the Spring of 2025, according to LEVEL-5 CEO Akihiro Hino, so we only have a few months to wait until we get more details about this bizarrely adorable follow-up to Yokai Watch!

entry.title: EA FC 25: How to perform Kylian Mbappe celebrations
entry.summary:
If Kylian Mbappe is your favorite footballer and you're wondering how to perform his celebrations in EA FC 25, we have you covered.
Real Madrid fans have another reason to rejoice after Kylian Mbappe joined Los Blancos, making him one of the highest-rated players in EA FC 25.
How to do Kylian Mbappe celebrations in EA FC 25?
In EA FC 25, Mbappe has two iconic celebrations, crossing his arms while standing and one where he knee slides and salutes with two fingers.
To perform the crossing arms celebration, simply:
Hold the L2 button and then press the O button twice (this is for PlayStation controllers)
For Xbox controllers, you can do it by holding the LT button and then tapping the B button twice.
This celebration is also known as "Little Brother", and is closely linked to Ethan Mbappe, a CDM from Ligue 1.
To perform the sliding salute celebration, simply:
Hold the R1 button and then hold the RS to the right (for PlayStation controllers)
Hold the RB button and then hold the RS to the right (for Xbox controllers)
Kylian Mbappe is also a huge Cristiano Ronaldo fanboy and he's known to replicate several of his iconic celebrations, including the Siu.

entry.title: The Plucky Squire review: a charming storybook adventure, but I wish it let you go full plucko mode
entry.summary: I really wanted to like action adventure The Plucky Squire more than I do now, having given its charming 2D to 3D platforming a proper whirl. Yes, it's lovely to look at. Yes, hopping out of a storybook and making friends with an illustration on a coffee mug is cool. And yes, everyone can have a mildly fun time with its puzzles and fights. But that's the problem: who is everyone? At first I thought, "This game is for young kids and that's fine!", given its relative simplicity. Then I hit some puzzles and thought, "Ain't no kid figuring this out". Then it hit me. It struggles to balance the fine line between being approachable for tiny tots and layered enough for people who've graduated from "goo goo ga ga" to "oo oo aa aa my back hurts". And that's down to how plucky you're allowed to squire at any given time, because it can be surprisingly limited and, sadly, a bit underwhelming. Read more

entry.title: UFO 50 review: a pixellated portrait of the 1980s that offers a strange sort of time travel
entry.summary: You can't travel back to the 1980s. But what if I told you it was possible to gently warp your memories of that time? UFO 50 is a kart of 50 games that once existed for an old computer system, all lovingly restored by a gang of coders. The old console, of course, is a fiction. The LX-I never existed. But it's a fun pseudo-history against which to create a grab bag of small games (some throwaway, others mighty) all designed with a distinct 80s look. It's an exercise in adhering to an aesthetic. Like an oil painter working with a limited range of colours, the developers of this bundle have stuck to a 32-colour equivalent of the Zorn palette. Yet play a little of each game, and you start to sense the smirk of chronos. These games aren't stuck in the past, but they are enjoying a holiday there. Read more

entry.title: We should redefine live service games as the living dead
entry.summary: Why is every blockbuster video game now some kind of live service game? Speaking as a clueless idiot, the explanation I find most convincing is that it's an attempt to bridge the gap between the returns publishers want from video games, versus how much we're able or willing to pay upfront. "Triple-A" projects now cost exorbitant sums to develop, partly thanks to wider economic inflation, but also because publishers have spent decades teaching players that every sequel has to be More and Shinier. Premium game prices have not risen in proportion, and investors want growth, as they do. Live service games sneak around this difficulty by dragging out the time we spend playing them. Whether premium or free-to-play, they seek to install themselves as habits by means of regular, planned updates and additions. This is time that can be monetised by way of a subscription model, time in which other products may be sold to you, like skins and paintjobs, and time that becomes a commodity in itself, "engagement", which can be transmuted and exploited to various end. I'm not sure it's ever been expressed this way in any press release boast about longevity, but the unspoken principle/logical extrapolation seems to be that ideally, a live service game should keep us plugged in and plugging away till we die. entry.title: People’s heads keep exploding for no good reason in I Am Your Beast and I’m very much onboard with it
entry.summary: Strange Scaffold’s newly released FPS I Am Your Beast is very fun for quite a few reasons, but chief among them is a deep appreciation for the poetry of good videogame violence. I’m not using the big P word just to throw out an overly worthy comparison to something we might associate with craft or beauty, but as a nod toward the game’s playful application of what I previously called ‘a euphoric splurge of murderous game verbiage’ one morning where I had clearly eaten my wordy Weetabix. The way its hurled knives and curb stomps and inexplicable decapitations flow together have an assonant, almost Suessian quality to them. But it’s also, well, just a bit like Mad Libs. You play as Harding, a man who’s mythical lethality is established very early on. The showing is there in the moment to moment, but the telling is conveyed through cute tricks like how everyone you meet is so deeply afraid of Harding that they loudly keep track of exactly what weapon he’s holding at all times. The Mad Libs comes in through the fact that you can draw Harding a route between A and B, and it’s a given that multiple heads are going to come unstuck from necks along the way. You’re sort of just casually filling in the verbs that seem the most fun to you in the moment. One of the verbs is ‘hornet’. Hornet is a verb now. Read more

entry.title: Trust is a vampire FPS with immersive sim elements from the Forgive Me Father devs
entry.summary:
In theory, vampires and immersive sims go together as naturally as bats and caves. Immersive sims tend to involve a balance of stealth, acrobatics, raw strength and crafty manipulation, and vampires are celebrated for all of these things. Despite this, actual vampire-themed immersive sims are rare. My list starts with Vampire: the Masquerade: Bloodlines... and sort of ends there. In a devastating betrayal, Arkane Austin's Redfall wasn't an immersive sim but an open world co-op shooter (a not very good one). The much-delayed Bloodlines 2 was recently downgraded from immersive sim to RPG by new developers The Chinese Room. Arkane Lyon's Blade adaptation seems promising, but it's a ways off.
Here to paper over the immersive vamping gap in the market is Byte Barrel's Trust, "a new first-person shooter with immersive sim elements". It takes place in a world where the vampires are hunted for their blood, which has become an everyday human energy source, used for everything from car batteries to streetlights. The irony! I feel like, in the circumstances, the ideal solution would be for humans to let vampires suck their blood in return for vampires letting humans use their blood for electricity, but that wouldn't make for a very thrilling shooter. Anyway, here's the trailer.

entry.title: Among the many beauties of Arco is that it's a secret, gentle introduction to bullet hell shooting
entry.summary:
There are many reasons to play and write about Arco. The Mesoamerican pixelart landscapes, for example - radiant, cloud-hung platters of land with people and buildings reduced to daubs of paint in the foreground. The fact that it's about witnessing and surviving colonial invasion, rather than the more familiar European or North American video game fantasy of searching a New World for plunder. The ensemble storytelling, with four, successively playable characters setting their own lenses to thickly entangled themes of sorrow, vengeance and growing understanding. The sparse, expressive dialogue, each phrase carefully tucked inside its speech bubble. The music. And the little things at the level of how you move, what you do. When you pick a faraway destination on your map, your character makes the journey screen by screen, which gives you a second to lean back and be a passenger, watching the horizon, at least until you're ambushed by a giant beetle.

entry.summary: Surrealistický artfilm, který by byl možná originální před 70 lety a zajímavě retro před 30 lety, ale dnes je především nudný a nemá k ničemu co říct. Je chvályhodné, pokud tento film pomůže zlepšit podmínky v dětských domovech, ale bez hromady doprovodných informací není ani zřejmé, že má mít nějaký takový účel. Z toho, co se děje na plátně, nevyplývá nic víc než "Podívejte, co se honí v mé šílené hlavě, zajímá vás to?" Mě osobně ne. (Ilča 20 %)
